prompt.p: A 64-year-old woman presents to her GP complaining of retrosternal chest pain exacerbated by eating. There is no radiation of pain and no shortness of breath. Chest examination is normal, as are an electrocardiogram and chest X-ray. Haematological investigation:
What medication is the cause of the patient's presentation?

modalFeedback.p: Option A (Alendronate) is Correct. Alendronate is a bisphosphonate that is used in osteoporosis. Tablets can cause erosion of the gastrointestinal tract, e.g. oesophagitis or gastric ulceration.

Option B (Carbimazole) is Incorrect. Agranulocytosis is a complication of this medication used to treat hyperthyroidism. Patients are warned to seek medical attention if they become ill with symptoms and sign of infection.
Option C (Metformin) is Incorrect. Metformin can rarely cause lactic acidosis which requires withdrawal of this treatment.
Option D (Prednisolone) is Incorrect. Prednisolone can cause iatrogenic Cushing's syndrome.
Option E (Thyroxine) is Incorrect. Levothyroxine can cause symptoms and signs of thyrotoxicosis.
